ã€Treatiseã€‘ Question:
The Buddha is like Mount Sumeru, unshaken by the waves of the great ocean. Why then does he answer SamantaprabhÄsa?
This is a sign of movement.
When the mind is concentrated, there is no speech. When the mind is scattered, there is speaking.
Expounding the Dharma arises from contemplation. Contemplation is a coarse matter. The Buddha should not have this coarse matter!
Answer:
Although the Buddha has entered deep meditation, he is not moved by worldly affairs. Now, with a mind of great compassion, he pities sentient beings and preaches the Dharma to resolve their doubts.
It is like Mount Sumeru, which cannot be moved by a small wind, but when the great wind arrives, it shakes and scatters greatly;

The Buddha is also like this. When the wind of great compassion arrives, his mind of pity moves, and his body scatters into countless forms, entering the five realms to teach and transform sentient beings, sometimes taking on the form of a deity or even an animal.
Furthermore, the Buddha is truly unmoving and always in meditation. Due to the causes and conditions of his past merits and virtues, sounds emerge from his body, responding to things like an echo;
It is like the music of the heavens, naturally sounding.
It is also like a mani jewel, which grants people's wishes and provides them with various things. If one desires clothing, food and drink, or music, one can freely obtain whatever one needs;
The Buddha is also like this. From the pores of his body, sounds naturally arise that expound the Dharma according to the mind. In this, the Buddha has no recollection or discrimination.
As it is said in the Sutra of the Secret Traces of Vajra, the Buddha has three secrets:
Secret body, secret speech, and secret mind.
All the heavenly beings and people do not understand or know them.
There are sentient beings in an assembly who may see the Buddha's body as the color of yellow gold, the color of white silver, or various precious colors;
Some people see the Buddha's body as sixteen feet tall, some as one li, ten li, a hundred thousand, ten million, up to boundless, immeasurable, pervading the sky. Such are called the secret body.
As for the secret speech, some people hear the Buddha's voice for one li, some hear it for ten li, a hundred thousand, ten million, countless, immeasurable, pervading the sky;

In one assembly, some heard the Buddha speak of giving, some heard him speak of upholding precepts, some heard him speak of forbearance, diligence, meditation, and wisdom, and so forth, up to the twelve divisions of the canon and the eighty thousand dharma aggregates. Each heard according to their mind. This is called the secret of speech.
At that time, MaudgalyÄyana thought:
I want to know how far the Buddha's voice reaches.

He immediately used his own supernormal powers to travel to worlds of immeasurable thousands of myriads of koá¹­is of buddhas, but he could still hear the Buddha's voice as if nearby, without any difference.
In the world where he stopped, the Buddha and his great assembly were just about to eat.
The people in that land were tall, and MaudgalyÄyana stood on the edge of their bowls. The Buddha's disciples asked their Buddha, saying:
Where did this man with a head insect come from?
He wears the robes of an ascetic but acts like this!
That Buddha replied:
Do not look down on this man!
This is the east, beyond innumerable buddha lands, where there is a buddha named ÅšÄkyamuni. This is his disciple with supernatural powers.
That buddha asked:
MaudgalyÄyana!
Why have you come here?
MaudgalyÄyana replied:
I have come here because I am following the Buddha's voice.
That buddha told MaudgalyÄyana:
If you follow the Buddha's voice, even after innumerable koá¹­Ä«s of kalpas, you will not be able to reach its end.
Moreover, the Buddha appears in the world in order to eliminate the doubts of sentient beings and teach the Dharma. This should not be questioned.
It is like asking:
Why does one remove darkness?
The Buddha is also like this.
One should not ask the Buddha why he answers.
Question:
Since all buddhas are equal, they are called equally enlightened. Why is it said now that this is his spiritual power?
Answer:
In order to show that there is no self and to eliminate jealousy and arrogance between each other.
Furthermore, there are gods in the world who always seek supremacy, due to the nature of arrogance, and say, Heaven, earth, humans, and things were created by me.
Like the Brahma Heaven King, who tells the Brahmas:
I created you all.
The Vishnu Heaven says:

In the world, those who are greatly wealthy, noble, and famous, are all due to the power and virtue of my body. I can accomplish the world and also destroy the world. The formation and destruction of the world are all created by me.
There are such gods who destroy the characteristics of the law of causes and conditions;
The true words of the Buddhas do not destroy the characteristics of the law of causes and conditions, so it is said it is the spiritual power of that Buddha.
Sutra: At that time, Bodhisattva SamantaprabhÄsa said to Buddha RatnÄkara:
World-Honored One!
I now wish to go and see ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha, to pay homage and make offerings;
and see those bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who have inherited the position of the Honored One, all attaining dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s and various samÄdhis, and attaining mastery over various samÄdhis.
[Treatise] Question:
If the buddhas are equal in upholding precepts, concentration, wisdom, and saving people, why does this Bodhisattva SamantaprabhÄsa wish to come and see ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha?
Answer:
Bodhisattvas always wish to see the Buddha without becoming complacent, listen to the Dharma without becoming complacent, and see the assembly of bodhisattvas without becoming complacent;
bodhisattvas are disgusted with all worldly dharmas, but their minds are never complacent with the above three things.
Just as the householder Hastaka came from the Pure Abodes to see the Buddha, his body was so subtle that it was about to disappear, like melting ghee, and he could not stand on the ground.
The Buddha told the householder Hastaka:
You should transform your body to be coarse and observe the characteristics of this ground!
The householder then transformed his body as the Buddha had instructed, contemplated the characteristics of this land, bowed his head to the Buddha's feet, and stood to one side.
The Buddha asked the householder:
How many things are you not tired of that you are born in the Pure Abodes?
He replied:
I am not tired of three things that I am born in the Pure Abodes:
First, seeing the buddhas and making offerings without being tired of it; second, listening to the Dharma without being tired of it; third, providing for the saá¹…gha without being tired of it.
Just as the Buddha is in JambudvÄ«pa, the fourfold assembly always follows the Buddha, listening to the Dharma and asking about the Dharma;
This is also how the gods of my Pure Abodes always follow me to listen to the Dharma and ask about the Dharma.
Even the hearers are still not tired of listening to the Dharma, let alone the bodhisattvas whose bodies are of the nature of Dharma?
For this reason, the bodhisattva SamantaprabhÄsa came to see ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha.
And seeing the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas here who will succeed to the honored position, all attain dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s and various samÄdhis, as explained in the Praising the Bodhisattvas Chapter above.
In the various samÄdhis, they attain mastery.
Question:
If only the Buddha, as one person, attains mastery in all samÄdhis, why is it said that the bodhisattvas also attain mastery in all samÄdhis?
Answer:
There are two kinds of samÄdhis:
first, the Buddha's samÄdhis, and second, the bodhisattvas' samÄdhis.
These bodhisattvas attain mastery in the bodhisattvas' samÄdhis, not in the Buddha's samÄdhis.
As it is said in the Sutra of the Gathering of the Essential Teachings of the Buddhas:
MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« wanted to see the gathering of the Buddhas, but he could not reach them.

The buddhas each returned to their original places. Manjushri came to where the buddhas had gathered. There was a woman sitting close to the Buddha, entering samadhi. Manjushri entered, bowed at the Buddha's feet, and said to the Buddha:
Why is it that this woman can sit close to the Buddha while I cannot?
The Buddha told Manjushri:
You awaken this woman and make her emerge from samadhi. You can ask her yourself.

Manjushri immediately snapped his fingers to awaken her, but she could not be awakened. He called out in a loud voice, and still she could not be awakened. He grabbed her hand and pulled, and still she could not be awakened. He then used his spiritual powers to shake the trichiliocosm, but she still did not awaken.
Manjushri said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
I cannot make her awaken.

At that time, the Buddha emitted a great light illuminating the world below. In it, there was a bodhisattva named Removing All Obscurations, who immediately emerged from below, came to where the Buddha was, bowed his head to the Buddha's feet, and stood to one side.
The Buddha said to the bodhisattva Removing All Obscurations:
You awaken this woman!
He then snapped his fingers, and the woman arose from her samÄdhi.
MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« addressed the Buddha, saying:
For what causes and conditions am I unable to cause this woman to arise by shaking the trichiliocosm?
Bodhisattva Removing All Obscurations snapped his fingers once, and she immediately arose from her samÄdhi?
The Buddha said to MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«:

You first gave rise to the intention to achieve supreme perfect enlightenment because of this woman, and this woman first gave rise to the intention to achieve supreme perfect enlightenment because of Bodhisattva Removing All Obscurations.
For this reason, you are unable to awaken her.
In the samÄdhi of all buddhas, your merit and virtue are not yet complete.
It is because these bodhisattvas have attained mastery in samÄdhi, but in the buddhas' samÄdhi, they have entered a little but not yet attained mastery.
[Sutra] The Buddha told SamantaprabhÄsa:
If you wish to go, you may do as you please. It is time.
At that time, Ratnasaá¹ƒbhava Buddha gave SamantaprabhÄsa a golden lotus flower with a thousand petals and told him:
Good man!
You should scatter this flower over ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha.
The bodhisattvas born in that SahÄ world are difficult to surpass and difficult to reach. You should go to that world with a focused mind!
[Treatise] Question:
Why did the Buddha say, If you wish to go, you may do as you please. It is time?
Answer:
Because the Buddha has cut off attachment to his disciples, and his mind is not attached to his disciples.

Furthermore, this bodhisattva has not yet attained omniscience and has not yet attained the Buddha's eye, so there is a little doubt in his mind, thinking that the merits of ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha are great and the benefits may be superior, so he says:
You may go as you wish.
Furthermore, this bodhisattva sees from afar that ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha's body is small and gives rise to a little arrogance in his mind, saying that that Buddha is not as good.
Therefore the Buddha tells him:
When you go, do not look at the Buddha's body and do not think of the world, but only listen to the Buddha's teaching of the Dharma!
Furthermore, this world is extremely far from the Saha world, at the very eastern edge.
These bodhisattvas hear the characteristics of the dharmas taught by ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha, which are exactly the same as the characteristics of the dharmas taught by Buddha RatnÄkara, and then say:
Although the world is far away, the characteristics of the dharmas are no different!
Increasing their great faith, their minds become even more firm.
Furthermore, due to causes and conditions from past lives, even if born far away, one should come to listen to the Dharma;
it is like a bird tethered with a string, even if it flies far away, it is drawn back.
Furthermore, the bodhisattvas in this SahÄ world, seeing SamantaprabhÄsa come from afar to listen to the Dharma, think like this:
He has come from far away, how much more so should I, born in this world, not listen to the Dharma?
For these various reasons, the Buddha said:
If you wish to go, you may do as you please, it is time for you to know.
Question:
The powers of the buddhas are equal, and they do not seek blessings, why then do they use flowers as a token of faith?
Answer:
It is because they follow the practices of worldly dharmas.
It is like the two kings, although their power is the same, they still exchange gifts with each other.
Furthermore, it is because they show a good and gentle mind that they use flowers as a token of faith.
In worldly dharmas, if a messenger comes from far away, there must be a token of faith;
The Buddha follows worldly dharmas, and therefore he gains faith.
Moreover, because the Buddhas respect the Dharma, they make offerings to the Dharma, taking the Dharma as their teacher.
Why is this?
The Buddhas of the three times all take the true characteristics of all dharmas as their teacher.
Question:
Why not make offerings to the Dharma in one's own body, but make offerings to other Dharmas?
Answer:

Following worldly dharmas, just as a bhiká¹£u wishes to make offerings to the Dharma Jewel, he does not make offerings to the Dharma in his own body, but makes offerings to others who uphold the Dharma, know the Dharma, and understand the Dharma;
The Buddha is also like this. Although there is Dharma in his body, he makes offerings to the Dharma of other Buddhas.
Question:
If the Buddha does not seek blessings and virtues, why make offerings?
Answer:
The Buddha has cultivated various merits for immeasurable incalculable eons, always practicing goodness, not only seeking rewards, but making offerings out of respect for merit and virtue.
Like when the Buddha was alive, there was a blind bhikkhu who could not see with his eyes and was sewing his robe with his hands. When the needle skipped a stitch, he said:
Who loves merit?
Please rethread my needle for me!
At that time, the Buddha came to his place and said to the bhikkhu:
I am the one who loves merit. I will come to rethread your needle for you!
The bhikkhu recognized the Buddha's voice, quickly got up, put on his robe, bowed at the Buddha's feet, and said to the Buddha:
The Buddha's merits are already complete. Why do you say you love merit?
The Buddha replied:

Although my merits are already complete, I deeply understand the grace of merit, the fruits of merit, and the power of merit, which enable me to attain the foremost position among all sentient beings.
Because of this merit, I therefore love it.
After the Buddha praised the merits for this bhikkhu, he then spoke the Dharma according to his wishes.
The bhikkhu attained the purity of the Dharma eye and his physical eyes became clearer.
Furthermore, although the Buddha's merits are already complete and he has no further needs, he speaks to his disciples in order to teach and transform them, saying:
I still make merit, how can you not make it?
It is like an old man of a hundred years dancing in a troupe. Someone scolds him, saying:
The old man is already a hundred years old, what use is this dancing?
The old man replies:
I do not need to dance, I just want to teach my children and grandchildren.
The Buddha is also like this. Although his merits are already complete, in order to teach his disciples to make merit, he makes offerings.
Question:
If that is so, why did the Buddha not himself scatter offerings from afar to ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha, but instead sent someone to make offerings?
Answer:
It is because the bodhisattvas here in this world have faith in Samantabhadra.
Furthermore, the messengers sent by the Buddha cannot be harmed by water, fire, weapons, or poison, in hundreds of thousands of ways;
The distance is far, so I want to ensure their safety.
Question:

Why not use precious treasures, profound scriptures, or the precious words of the Buddha and bodhisattvas, treasures that are unseen by the gods and can produce various wonderful things like a wish-fulfilling jewel, and call them the Buddha's treasures for trust, but instead use lotus flowers?
Lotus flowers are small things, how can they be sufficient as a token of trust?
Answer:
The Buddha does not need things. He does not even need the treasures of the Buddha or the gods, let alone the treasures of humans!
Because he does not need them, he does not send them. He also does not send them because he himself is equal to them.
The profound scriptures are also like this.
Furthermore, for the Buddha, all scriptures are not profound. The designation of profundity comes from ordinary people themselves.
What ordinary people doubt is unobstructed for the Buddha;
what ordinary people find difficult, the Buddha makes easy.
Furthermore, the fragrance of flowers is pure and wonderful, suitable for making offerings;
when people present gifts, they must use unusual things.
Question:
Why is it that only lotus flowers are used, and not other things?
The answer is:
Worship is only with flowers, incense, banners, and canopies;
Flowers have two functions:
They have color and fragrance.
The question is:
Other flowers also have fragrance and color, why is it that only lotus flowers are used for worship?
The answer is:
As explained in the Flower-Filled World Sutra:
The Buddhas of the ten directions all use flowers to worship Shakyamuni Buddha.
Furthermore, there are three kinds of lotus flowers:
First, human flowers; second, heavenly flowers; third, bodhisattva flowers.
Human flowers are large lotus flowers with ten or so petals;
Heavenly flowers have a hundred petals;
Bodhisattva flowers have a thousand petals.

In that world, there are many golden-colored thousand-petaled lotus flowers. In the Saha world, there are only transformed thousand-petaled flowers, not water-born ones. For this reason, they are sent.
This lotus has a thousand petals and is golden in color, as explained above in the section on the tongue faculty.
Question:
Why does the Buddha have SamantaprabhÄsa scatter flowers over the Buddha?
Answer:
The Dharma is to be worshipped with flowers, incense, banners, and canopies:
Banners and canopies should be placed above, dry incense should be burned, wet incense should be applied to the ground, and powdered incense and flowers should be scattered.
Question:
Why not just make offerings and be done with it, but rather scatter them oneself?
Answer:
Personally making offerings is the bodily action, softly speaking greetings is the verbal action, and being able to give rise to bodily and verbal actions is the mental action.
These three actions attain firm merit and serve as causes and conditions for Buddhahood.
Question:
Why is it said, You should single-mindedly respectfully and carefully consider that in the SahÄ world, the bodhisattvas are difficult to reach and difficult to surpass?
Answer:
The Buddhas, pratyekabuddhas, arhats, and all sages all single-mindedly respectfully and carefully consider.

MÄra, his minions, and the afflictions within one's own body, as well as the various karmic retributions from past lives, are all thieves. Because one is close to these various thieves, one should respectfully guard one's mind.
It is like entering among thieves. If one does not carefully protect oneself, one will be robbed by the thieves.
For this reason, it is said, Respectfully guard one's mind and roam in that realm.
Moreover, the human mind is often scattered, like one who is mad or drunk.
Respectfully guarding one's mind is the initial gateway to all merits.
By concentrating the mind and attaining meditation, one then attains true wisdom.
By attaining true wisdom, one then attains liberation.
By attaining liberation, one then attains the end of suffering.
Such matters all arise from a single mind.
One hundred years after the Buddha's parinirvÄá¹‡a, there was a bhiká¹£u named Upagupta who attained the six supernatural powers and arhatship. At that time, he became the great guide of JambudvÄ«pa.
At that time, there was a nun who was 120 years old. This nun had seen the Buddha when she was young.
Upagupta came to her house, wanting to ask about the Buddha's appearance. He first sent his disciple.
The disciple said to the nun:
My great teacher Upagupta wants to come and see you, to ask about the Buddha's appearance.
At that time, the nun filled a bowl with sesame oil and placed it under the door to test whether his demeanor was careful or not.
Upagupta entered and slowly pushed open the door, and a little sesame oil was spilled.
After sitting down, he asked the nun:
Have you seen the Buddha?
What was his appearance like?
Please tell me.
The nun replied:
At that time, I was young. I saw the Buddha come into the village. The people said the Buddha had come, and I also followed the people out. Seeing the light, I immediately paid homage.
A golden hairpin fell on the ground in a dark forest. The Buddha's light illuminated it, and everything in the darkness was seen. She immediately found the hairpin.
Since then, I became a bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«.
UpÄli asked again:
What were the rules and etiquette of the bhiká¹£us during the Buddha's time like?
She replied:
During the Buddha's time, the group of six bhiká¹£us were shameless and the most wicked;
their rules and etiquette were better than yours today.
How do I know this?
The group of six bhiká¹£us did not waste oil when entering a house.
Although they were wicked, they knew the rules and etiquette of bhiká¹£us, and did not lose the rules when walking, standing, sitting, or lying down;
although you are an arhat with the six spiritual powers, you are not as good as them!
When UpÄli heard these words, he was greatly ashamed of himself!
For this reason, it is said to be respectfully cautious with a single mind.
Being respectfully cautious with a single mind is a characteristic of a good person.
Next, why is it said that with a single mind of respect and caution, this bodhisattva is difficult to surpass, difficult to reach, difficult to break, and difficult to approach?
It is like a great lion king, difficult to surpass and difficult to break;
It is also like a white elephant king and a dragon king, like a great flame, all difficult to approach.

Because this bodhisattva has the power of great merit and wisdom, if people want to surpass or break him, it is impossible, and they will only break themselves. Therefore, it is said that he is difficult to approach.
Question:
All great bodhisattvas have great merit, wisdom, and sharp faculties. All are difficult to approach. Why is it said that only the bodhisattvas in the SahÄ world are difficult to approach?
Answer:
It is indeed as you say.

But because the bodhisattvas from the world of Many Treasures came from afar and saw that this world is inferior, with stones, sand, and filth, and the bodhisattvas' bodies are small, and all things are also inferior, they will certainly give rise to contempt. Therefore, the Buddha said:
With a single-pointed mind, respect and be careful, those bodhisattvas are difficult to approach.
Furthermore, people born in places of pleasure are often not vigorous, not intelligent, and have little wisdom.
Like the people of Uttarakuru, because of great pleasure, there is no renunciation, no precepts;
it is the same in the heavens.

In this SahÄ world, the causes of pleasure are few, there are the three evil destinies, old age, sickness, and death, and the methods of livelihood in the land are difficult, therefore, it is easy to give rise to a mind of disgust.
Seeing old age, sickness, and death arrive, the mind greatly despises them;
seeing poor people, knowing what is caused by past karma, the mind gives rise to great disgust.
Therefore, the faculties of wisdom are sharp.

In those places, bodhisattvas in worlds of the seven treasures, with various jeweled trees, thinking of food and drink, obtaining it as soon as they wish, it is difficult to give rise to a mind of disgust like this, therefore, wisdom cannot greatly benefit.
It is like a sharp knife that becomes stained when placed in good food. Although the food is good, it is not suitable for the knife.
If it is ground on a stone and polished with grease and ash, the stains are removed and the knife becomes sharp.
The bodhisattvas are also like this. They are born in mixed worlds and have sharp wisdom that is difficult to approach.
It is like a person who has suffered hardships since childhood, who is capable of many things and can endure much.
It is also like a horse that is not ridden and therefore has no use.
Furthermore, the bodhisattvas in this SahÄ world are difficult to approach because they have many skillful means, which is not the case in other places.
As the Buddha said:
I remember from my past lives that I once saved a thousand people in one day.

For the sake of saving sentient beings, although I had all the merits and the six pÄramitÄs and all the Buddha's work was complete, I did not become a Buddha, but always used skillful means to save and liberate sentient beings.
For this reason, the bodhisattvas in this SahÄ world are difficult to approach.

Sutra: At that time, Bodhisattva Universal Radiance received a golden lotus flower with a thousand petals from Buddha Jeweled Accumulation, and together with countless ordained and lay bodhisattvas, as well as young men and women, they set out.
Treatise: Question:

Since this Bodhisattva Universal Radiance has great spiritual powers, he should be able to come. But how did the ordained and lay bodhisattvas, as well as the young men and women, get there by themselves?
The world of Abundant Treasures is farthest to the east, the journey is long, did they travel there by their own power?
Was it the power of Buddha Jeweled Accumulation?
Was it the power of Bodhisattva Universal Radiance?
Or was it the power of Shakyamuni Buddha?
Answer:
It is the power of all four.

Whether they are renunciant or householder bodhisattvas, or bodhisattvas who have attained the five supernatural powers without regression, they have well cultivated the four bases of supernatural power. Due to the causes and conditions of ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha in their past lives, they rely on their own power as well as the power of Bodhisattva Samantabhadra. Why is this?
Those with weak power are able to come here due to the power of Bodhisattva Samantabhadra.
When a wheel-turning sage king flies up to the heavens, his four kinds of troops, palaces, and animals all fly with him.
This is because the merit and virtue of the wheel-turning sage king is so great that he can cause everything to fly with him.
It is the same here. Those with weak power are able to come here due to the power of Bodhisattva Samantabhadra.
This is also the power of Buddha Ratnasaá¹ƒbhava, as well as the illumination of ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha's light.
If they had no power of their own, but were only illuminated by ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha's light, they would still be able to come, let alone when there are three [factors].
Question:
Why did this Bodhisattva SamantaprabhÄsa not come alone but with many people?
Answer:
It is because the retinue is appropriate.
It is like when a king goes out, he must have attendants.
Furthermore, this Bodhisattva SamantaprabhÄsa and ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha have a karmic connection.
Why is it so?
Because the two groups in that great assembly came together, therefore it is known that those with karmic connections come, and those without karmic connections stay.
Question:
Why did this Bodhisattva come together with lay and ordained men and women?
Answer:
The Buddha's disciples are in seven groups:
bhiká¹£us, bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s, Å›iká¹£amÄá¹‡Äs, Å›rÄmaá¹‡eras, Å›rÄmaá¹‡erÄ«s, upÄsakas, and upÄsikÄs.
UpÄsakas and upÄsikÄs are lay people, while the other five groups are renunciant.
Within the renunciant and lay groups, there are two more types:
those who are great and those who are small.
The younger ones are the boys and girls;
The rest are the elders.
Question:
The elders should go, why can the younger ones come?
Answer:
It is in merit and virtue, not in age.
If one loses the benefits of merit and virtue and practices unwholesome dharmas, one is old but young;
If one has the benefits of merit and virtue and practices wholesome dharmas, one is young but old.
Furthermore, these younger ones have come from afar, and when people see them, they praise:
Young and yet able to do this, coming from afar for the Dharma!
It also shows that in the Buddha's teachings, both the young and the old can practice.
In the teachings of non-Buddhists, only Brahmins can practice their teachings, not non-Brahmins;
In the Buddha's teachings, there is no distinction between young and old, no inside and outside, and everyone can practice.
It is like taking medicine, the main thing is to cure the illness, regardless of the status or age of the patient.
Sutra: All of them made offerings, paid respects, revered, and praised the Buddhas in the east.
Treatise: Question:
If they all make offerings to the Buddhas in the east, and there are so many Buddhas, when will it be completed, and they can come here?
Answer:
These bodhisattvas do not make offerings according to the human or heavenly way, but according to the bodhisattva way.

The bodhisattva way of making offerings is to enter meditation with the body, and from the sides of the body, countless bodies emerge, transforming into various offering items, filling the Buddha worlds.
It is like when a dragon king moves, water emerges from its body and rains down everywhere.
Question:
Since these bodhisattvas want to go to Shakyamuni Buddha, why do they make offerings to the Buddhas along the way?
Answer:
The Buddhas are the supreme field of blessings. If one makes offerings, one will receive great rewards.
It is like a person who extensively cultivates fields in order to obtain much grain.
The bodhisattvas see that by making offerings to the buddhas, they attain the rewards of buddhahood, and therefore make offerings.
Moreover, the bodhisattvas always revere the buddhas, just as a person reveres their parents.

The bodhisattvas receive the Buddha's teachings, attain various samÄdhis, various dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s, and various spiritual powers, and because they know the kindness [of the Buddha], they make extensive offerings.
As it says in the Lotus Sutra, when the bodhisattva Medicine King received from the Buddha the samÄdhi of manifesting all forms, he had this thought:
How should I make offerings to the Buddha and the Lotus SamÄdhi?
He then flew to the heavens and, through the power of the samÄdhi, rained down the seven treasures, flowers, incense, banners, and canopies to make offerings to the Buddha.
Emerging from the samÄdhi, he still felt it was insufficient.
For 1,200 years, he ingested various fragrances, drank fragrant oils, then wrapped his body in heavenly white cloth and burned himself, making this vow:
May my bodily radiance illuminate the worlds of the Buddhas as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River!
The Buddhas in the worlds as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River praised him, saying:
Excellent!ğŸ”½Excellent!
Good man!
Making offerings with one's body is the foremost!
It surpasses making offerings with one's country, city, wife, and children by hundreds of thousands of millions of times, and cannot be compared to.
For 1,200 years, his body burned without extinguishing.

Furthermore, making offerings to the Buddha brings immeasurable fame, merit, and benefits. All unwholesome deeds are completely eliminated, and all wholesome roots increase. In this life and future lives, one always receives offerings in return, and after a long time, one becomes a Buddha.
Thus, making offerings to the Buddha brings various immeasurable benefits.
For this reason, the bodhisattvas make offerings to the Buddha.
Sutra: Holding various flowers, incense, necklaces, powdered incense, fragrant ointments, burning incense, ointments, clothing, banners, and canopies, they went to where Shakyamuni Buddha was.
Having arrived, they bowed their heads to the Buddha's feet and stood to one side.
Treatise: Question:
One should say bowed, why is it called bowed their heads to the Buddha's feet?
Answer:
The most precious part of the human body is the head, as the five senses are concentrated there and it is the highest part;
the feet are the least precious, as they tread in impure places and are the lowest part.
Therefore, using the most precious to pay homage to the least precious is the most valuable offering.
Furthermore, there are three levels of paying homage:
the lowest is bowing, the middle is kneeling, and the highest is bowing one's head;
bowing one's head to the Buddha's feet is the highest offering.
For this reason, in the Buddha's Vinaya, a junior monk holds the feet of the senior monk with both hands and bows his head to them.
Question:
There are four kinds of bodily postures:
sitting, standing, walking, and lying down. Why stand on one side?
The answer is:
In order to come, one should not walk; in order to show respect and make offerings, one should not lie down. This matter is easy to understand, so why ask?
One should ask about sitting or standing.
Sitting means not taking offerings seriously;
standing means respectfully making offerings.
Furthermore, in the Buddha's teachings, non-Buddhist renunciants and all laypeople come to the Buddha and sit.
Non-Buddhists and other teachings slight the Buddha, so they sit;
laypeople are like guests, so they sit;
all five groups of disciples belong to the Buddha in body and mind, so they stand.
Arhats who have attained the Way, such as ÅšÄriputra, MaudgalyÄyana, SubhÅ«ti, and others, have accomplished what they needed to do, so they are allowed to sit;
Although the others have attained the three paths, they are not allowed to sit, because their great matter is not yet accomplished and the thief has not yet been defeated.
It is like a king's minister who has made great meritorious achievements and is therefore allowed to sit.
Among these bodhisattvas, although there are laypeople, they stand because they have come from afar to make offerings to the Buddha.ğŸ”½The sÅ«tra says:
Bodhisattva MahÄsattva RatnÄkara asked the Buddha:
The TathÄgata Ratnasaá¹ƒbhava inquires about the World-Honored One's well-being:
Are there few troubles, few illnesses, light activities, and is your strength at ease?
He also offered to the World-Honored One a golden lotus flower with a thousand petals.
The treatise asks:

The Buddha Ratnasaá¹ƒbhava is omniscient, so why does he only inquire about ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha's well-being, asking if he has few troubles, few illnesses, light activities, and whether his strength is at ease?
The answer is:
It is the way of the buddhas to know and yet ask.
As in the Vinaya, when the bhiká¹£u DÄrdhÄá¹…ganÄ built a red clay cave, the Buddha saw it and knew it, and asked:
Ä€nanda!
What is this for?
Ä€nanda said to the Buddha:

This is a potter's son who went forth, named DattÅ«ra. He built a small grass hut, which was always destroyed by cowherds. He built it three times and it was destroyed three times, so he built this tile hut.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
Destroy this tile cave!
Why is that?
Non-Buddhists will say:
'When the Buddha, the Great Teacher, was alive, the Dharma of leaks came out!'
In this way, he knew the circumstances everywhere but still asked.

Furthermore, although the Buddha is omniscient, he follows the laws of the world. When worldly people greet him, the Buddha also greets them. The Buddha was born among humans and follows human customs. He is the same as others in terms of cold, heat, birth and death. The way of greeting should also be the same.
Moreover, in the world, the greatly noble and the greatly humble should not greet each other;
because the Buddha is equal in power, they should greet each other.
Furthermore, the pure adornments of the world of PrabhÅ«taratna and the Buddha's body and appearance and radiance are also great. If one does not greet him, people will think it is disrespectful.

Moreover, he wishes to show that although the Buddha's world and body and appearance and radiance are superior in various ways, their wisdom and spiritual powers are equal and no different. Therefore, he greets him.
Question:
Why does he ask about having few illnesses and few troubles?
Answer:
There are two kinds of illnesses:
First, illnesses caused by external conditions, and second, illnesses caused by internal conditions.
As for the external, cold, heat, hunger, thirst, weapons, knives, sticks, falling, collapsing, and being crushed, and various other external afflictions are called troubles.
As for the internal, not moderating diet, sleeping and rising irregularly, the four hundred and four diseases, and various other kinds are called internal illnesses.
Since these two kinds of illnesses are suffering for all who have a body, therefore he asks:
Do you have few troubles and few illnesses?
Question:
Why not ask about being without distress and without illness, but ask about having little distress and having little illness?
Answer:
The sages truly know that the body is the root of suffering and is never without illness.
Why is this?
The four great elements come together to form the body. Earth, water, fire, and wind are by nature incompatible and harm each other.
It is like a festering sore that is never without pain. If one applies medicine, it can be slightly alleviated but cannot be cured;
The human body is also like this. It is always sick and always treated. Because of treatment, one lives. Without treatment, one dies.
For this reason, one cannot ask about being without distress and without illness.
External afflictions always have wind, rain, cold, and heat as distress.
Moreover, there are the four deportments of the body:
Sitting, lying down, walking, and standing. Staying seated for a long time is extremely distressing. Staying lying down, staying standing, and staying walking for a long time are all distressing.
For this reason, he asks about having few troubles and few illnesses.
Question:
Asking about having few troubles and few illnesses is sufficient, why does he also say are you getting along well?
Answer:
Although a person's illness may be cured, they have not yet fully recovered, for this reason he asks about getting along well.
Question:
Why does he say are you at ease and happy?
Answer:

There are people whose illnesses are cured, and although they can walk, sit, and rise, their strength is not yet sufficient to carry out tasks, to lift the light and move the heavy, therefore he asks about their strength.
There are people who, although their illnesses are cured and they can lift the heavy and move the light, have not yet experienced peace and happiness, therefore he asks:
Are you at ease and happy?
Question:
If there is no illness and one has strength, why have you not yet experienced peace and happiness?
Answer:
There are people who are poor, fearful, and sorrowful, and do not experience peace and happiness, for this reason he asks:
Are you at ease?
Furthermore, there are two kinds of methods for inquiring about someone's well-being:
Inquiring about the body and inquiring about the mind.
If one says little trouble, little illness, light and comfortable daily activities, and vigorous energy, this is inquiring about the body.
If one says are you at ease, this is inquiring about the mind.
Various internal and external illnesses are called bodily illnesses;
Lust, anger, jealousy, greed, worry, fear, and other various afflictions, the ninety-eight bonds, five hundred fetters, and various desires are called mental illnesses.
Because each of these illnesses is inquired about, it is said little trouble, little illness, light and comfortable daily activities, and vigorous energy, are you at ease?
Question:
If one inquires about someone's well-being, it should be so. Even the gods should not inquire about someone's well-being in this way, let alone the Buddha.
Answer:
The Buddha's body is of two kinds:
First, the body of spiritual powers and transformations, second, the body born from parents.
The body born from parents, because it receives human dharmas, is not as good as the heavenly body, therefore one should inquire about it according to human dharmas.
Question:

All sages and saints have no attachments in their minds, they do not crave the body, do not begrudge life, do not hate death, and do not delight in birth. If this is so, then what is the use of inquiring about it?
Answer:
Because they follow the dharmas of the world, they receive human dharmas and inquire about them.
Sending inquiries is also according to human dharmas.
A golden lotus flower with a thousand petals is as explained above.

The Sutra says: At that time, Shakyamuni Buddha received this golden lotus flower with a thousand petals and scattered it among the Buddhas in worlds as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River in the east.
The Treatise asks:
The Buddha is unsurpassed, so why now does he face the Buddhas in the east and scatter flowers to make offerings?
It is like when the Buddha first attained enlightenment, he thought to himself:
If people have no one to revere, their work will not be accomplished. Now, in the ten directions and between heaven and earth, who is worthy of reverence and service?
I wish to take the Buddha as my teacher and serve him!
At that time, the Brahma Heaven Kings and other gods said to the Buddha:
The Buddha is unsurpassed, there is no one who surpasses the Buddha.
The Buddha also observed with his heavenly eye that in the three periods of time and the ten directions and between heaven and earth, there was no one superior to the Buddha. He thought to himself:
I practiced the perfection of great wisdom and now have become a Buddha. He is the one I revere, he is my teacher. I should revere, make offerings to, and serve this Dharma.

It is like a tree called Haojian. This tree has been in the ground for a hundred years, with branches and leaves complete, and in one day it grows a hundred feet tall. After the tree has grown, it seeks a large tree to shade it.
At that time, there was a spirit in the forest who said to the Haojian tree:
In the world, there is none greater than you. All trees will be shaded by you.

The Buddha is also like this. For immeasurable asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas, he was born in the stage of the bodhisattva. In one day, he sat under the bodhi tree, on the vajra seat, and truly understood the characteristics of all dharmas, attaining the path of Buddhahood.
At that time, he thought to himself:
Who is worthy of respect and can be taken as a teacher? I should serve and make offerings to him with reverence.
Then, the Brahma kings and other gods said to the Buddha:
The Buddha is unsurpassed. There is none who surpasses the Buddha.
Why then do you now make offerings to the Buddhas of the east?
The answer is:
Although the Buddha is unsurpassed, and there is none who surpasses the Buddha in the worlds of the three times and the ten directions, he still makes offerings.
Making offerings has superior, middling, and inferior levels:ğŸ”½Making offerings to those who are inferior to oneself is an inferior offering;
Making offerings to those who are superior to oneself is a superior offering;ğŸ”½...
Making offerings equal to oneself refers to offerings made to oneself.
Making offerings to the buddhas is making offerings to oneself.
Just as the bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä« MahÄprajÄpatÄ«, together with five hundred bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s who had attained arhatship, entered nirvÄá¹‡a in one day and at one time.
At that time, the upÄsakas who had attained the three paths carried five hundred beds;
the four heavenly kings carried the bed of MahÄprajÄpatÄ«, the Buddha's foster mother;
the Buddha himself held an incense burner in front, burning incense to make offerings.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
You should help me make offerings to the body of my foster mother.
At that time, the arhat bhiká¹£us each used their supernormal powers to go to Mount MÄlaya, fetch ox-head sandalwood incense wood, and help the Buddha build a pyre, which is the lower offering.
For this reason, although one does not seek the fruit, one still makes equal offerings.
Furthermore, only the Buddha should make offerings to the Buddha, as other people do not know the Buddha's virtues.
As a verse says:
The wise can respect the wise, and the wise rejoice in the wise teachings;
The wise can know the wise, just as a snake knows its own foot.
For this reason, all the Buddhas, with their omniscience, can make offerings to all that is wise.
Furthermore, the Buddhas of the ten directions have generation after generation encouraged and assisted Shakyamuni Buddha.
Just as a bodhisattva at the seventh stage contemplates the emptiness and non-existence of all dharmas, without arising or ceasing.
Having contemplated in this way, their minds do not become attached to any world, and they wish to abandon the six perfections and enter nirvana.
It is like a person in a dream building a raft to cross a great river, with their hands and feet tired, giving rise to thoughts of weariness.
While in the middle of the current, they wake up from the dream and think to themselves:
Where is there a river to be crossed?
At that time, they completely let go of their diligent mind.
Bodhisattvas are also like this. In the seventh stage, they attain the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas, and all mental activities cease, wishing to enter nirvÄá¹‡a.
At that time, the buddhas of the ten directions all emit light, illuminating the bodhisattvas' bodies, and with their right hands they pat their heads, saying:
Good sons!
Do not give rise to this thought!
You should remember your original vow to deliver sentient beings.
Although you understand emptiness, sentient beings do not comprehend. You should gather various merits and teach and transform sentient beings, together entering nirvÄá¹‡a!
You have not yet attained the golden-colored body, the thirty-two marks, the eighty minor marks, immeasurable radiance, and the thirty-two kinds of activity.
You have now only attained one gate of the non-arising of dharmas. Do not be overjoyed!
At that time, the bodhisattvas heard the teachings of the buddhas and gave rise to their original minds again, practicing the six perfections to deliver sentient beings.
In this way, when they first attained buddhahood, they attained this assistance.
Moreover, when the Buddha first attained enlightenment, he thought to himself:
This Dharma is profound, and sentient beings are foolish and of little merit. I was also born in a world of the five turbidities. What should I do now?
Having thought this, he continued, I will divide this one Dharma into three parts, and with the three vehicles I will deliver sentient beings.
When he had this thought, the Buddhas of the ten directions all manifested their light and praised him, saying:
Excellent! Excellent!
We too, in the worlds of the five turbidities, have divided the one Dharma into three parts to deliver sentient beings.
At that time, the Buddha heard the voices of the Buddhas of the ten directions and was greatly delighted, exclaiming:
Homage to the Buddhas!
In this way, the Buddhas of the ten directions encouraged and assisted him, bringing great benefit. Knowing the heaviness of his gratitude, he offered flowers to the Buddhas of the ten directions.
There is no merit superior to this merit.
Why is it so?
These jeweled flowers are born from the power of the merit of Buddha, not from water.
SamantÄvabhÄsa is a bodhisattva in the tenth stage of the Dharma body, who sends these flowers to ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha.
ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha knows that the Buddhas of the ten directions are the foremost field of merit, so he makes offerings to them, and this merit is doubled.
Why is this?
Because the Buddha himself makes offerings to the Buddhas.
There are four kinds of giving in the Buddha's teachings:
1. The giver is pure, but the receiver is impure;
2. The giver is impure, but the receiver is pure;
3. Both the giver and the receiver are pure;
4. Both the giver and the receiver are impure.
Now, giving to the Buddhas of the east is the purest of the four, and this merit is the greatest.
For this reason, the Buddha himself makes offerings to the Buddhas of the ten directions.
Question:
All sages do not receive retribution, and will not be reborn again. Why do you say that this is the greatest merit of giving?
Answer:
Although this merit is not received by anyone, its form is great by itself;
If there are people who receive it, its reward is immeasurable.
Because the sages know that all conditioned dharmas are impermanent and empty, they abandon them and enter nirvana. This merit is also abandoned;
It is like a burning gold ball. Although the eyes see its beauty, it cannot be touched with the hand, because it will burn the hand.
Furthermore, it is like a person with a wound who needs medicine to apply to it;
If there is no wound, the medicine has no use.
A person with a body is also like this. It is always oppressed by hunger, thirst, cold, and heat, and is also like a wound erupting;
Using clothing, food and drink, warmth and comfort, is like applying medicine to a wound.
It is like a foolish person who, because of greed for medicine, does not use it to heal wounds;
If there are no wounds, the medicine is also useless.
The Buddhas regard the body as a wound, and because they abandon the wound of the body, they also do not receive the medicine of retribution.
For this reason, although they have great blessings, they also do not receive retribution.
[Sutra] The scattered lotus flowers filled the worlds in the east, as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River.
[Treatise] Question:
The flowers are few, and the worlds are many. How can they be filled?
Answer:
Because of the Buddha's supernormal powers, like the above eight kinds of self-indulgent transformation methods:

The great can be made small, the small can be made great, the light can be made heavy, the heavy can be made light, one is free and unhindered, one can reach wherever one wishes, one can shake the great earth, and one can accomplish one's wishes.
All great sages attain these eight kinds of mastery. Therefore, the Buddha can fill the worlds in the east, as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River, with a few flowers.
Moreover, it shows sentient beings the future rewards of blessings, filling the worlds in the east with such few flowers.
He also encouraged the bodhisattvas in the east, saying, Cultivate blessings in the Buddha-field, and the fruits and rewards obtained will also be like these flowers filling immeasurable lands;
Although you have come from afar, you should rejoice, encountering this great field of blessings, with immeasurable fruits and rewards!
[Sutra] On each flower there was a bodhisattva, sitting cross-legged, expounding the six perfections;
Those who heard this Dharma would eventually reach supreme, perfect enlightenment.
[Shastra] Question:
Above, the Buddha used the light of his tongue to transform into jeweled lotuses with a thousand petals, and on each flower there was a seated Buddha;
Now, why is it that on each flower there is a seated bodhisattva?
Answer:
Above, it was the flowers transformed by the Buddha, so there were seated Buddhas;
These are the flowers offered by the bodhisattva Samantabhadra, so there are seated bodhisattvas.
Furthermore, the above sentient beings should see the Buddha sitting to be liberated, and now this sentient being should see the Bodhisattva sitting to be liberated.
Sitting cross-legged, he expounds the six perfections;
Those who hear this Dharma will eventually reach anuttara-samyak-sambodhi, as previously explained.

[Sutra] The renunciant and householder bodhisattvas, and the young men and women, bowed their heads at the feet of Shakyamuni Buddha and each made offerings to Shakyamuni Buddha with various offerings, paying homage, respecting him, and praising him.

These renunciant and householder bodhisattvas, and the young men and women, each used the power of their wholesome roots and blessings to make offerings to Shakyamuni Buddha, the Tathagata, Arhat, Samyak-sambuddha.
[Treatise] As a verse says:
The path that the sages come by, the Buddha also comes by in the same way;
The true nature and the destination, the Buddha is also like this, without difference;
The sages speak the truth, the Buddha also speaks the truth;
For this reason, he is called the Buddha, the TathÄgata.
The armor of patience and a firm mind, the strength of the bow of diligence,
The sharp arrow of wisdom, breaking through the thieves of arrogance and conceit.
He should receive offerings from the heavens and humans of the world,
For this reason, he is called the Buddha, the Arhat.
Correctly knowing the true nature of suffering, also truly knowing the origin of suffering,
Knowing the true nature of the cessation of suffering, also knowing the path to the cessation of suffering.
Truly understanding the four noble truths, definitely real and immutable,
For this reason, he is called the Samyak-Saá¹ƒbuddha in the ten directions.
Attaining the subtle three insights, also perfecting the pure practices,
For this reason, he is called the World-Honored One, the ViÅ›vabhÅ«.
Understanding all dharmas, attaining the wondrous path oneself,
Sometimes expediently speaking, out of compassion for all.
Eliminating old age, sickness, and death, enabling one to reach a place of peace and security,
Therefore called Buddha, also called Sugata.
Knowing the source of the world, also knowing the path to the cessation of the world,
Therefore called Buddha, also called Lokavid.
The eyes of meditation, precepts, and wisdom, none can compare, let alone surpass,
Therefore called Buddha, also called Anuttara.
With great compassion, liberating sentient beings, gently guiding and taming,
Therefore called Buddha, also called PÅ«rá¹‡a MaitrÄyaá¹‡Ä«putra.
Wisdom without afflictions, expounding the supreme liberation,
Therefore called Buddha, also called Deva Manuá¹£ya.
The moving and unmoving in the three times, the exhausted and inexhaustible dharmas,

Under the bodhi tree, he knew all, and thus is called the Buddha.ğŸ”½The sutra says: To the south, passing buddha-realms as numerous as the sands of the Ganges, at the very edge there is a world called 'Free from All Sorrow,' with a buddha named 'Virtuous Freedom' and a bodhisattva named 'Free from Sorrow.'

To the west, passing buddha-realms as numerous as the sands of the Ganges, at the very edge there is a world called 'Eliminating Evil,' with a buddha named 'Jewel Mountain' and a bodhisattva named 'Deferential Intention.'

To the north, passing buddha-realms as numerous as the sands of the Ganges, at the very edge there is a world called 'Superior,' with a buddha named 'Superior King' and a bodhisattva named 'Attaining Victory.'

Below, passing buddha-realms as numerous as the sands of the Ganges, at the very edge there is a world called 'Good,' with a buddha named 'Virtuous Goodness' and a bodhisattva named 'Flower Superior.'
Above, across worlds as numerous as the sands of the Ganges, there is a world called Joy, with a Buddha named Joyful Virtue, and a Bodhisattva named Attaining Joy.
All are like this in the east.
[Treatise] Question:
In the Buddha's teachings, there are no real directions. Why is this?
They are not included among the five aggregates, twelve sense fields, or eighteen elements, nor are they in the four Dharma repositories.

Speaking of directions as real dharmas, seeking them through causes and conditions is also unobtainable. Why then are Buddhas of the ten directions and Bodhisattvas of the ten directions mentioned here?
Answer:
Following the transmitted worldly conventions, directions are spoken of, but seeking directions, they are unobtainable.
Question:
Why speak of no directions?ğŸ”½You do not speak of them in your four Dharma repositories, but we speak of them in our six Dharma repositories.
You do not include them among the aggregates, sense fields, or elements, but we include them among the dharmas.
This direction method is characterized by permanence and existence, and is both existent and permanent.
As it is said in the sutra:
Where the sun rises is the east, where the sun sets is the west, where the sun travels is the south, and where the sun does not travel is the north.
The sun has three parts:
the past part, the present part, and the future part.
Following the direction of the sun, the first part is the east, and the south and west are the same.
The place where the sun does not travel is without parts.
The other side and this side, the other and this, are the characteristics of direction;
if there were no direction, there would be no other side or this side, and the other and this are the characteristics of direction but not direction itself.
Answer:
This is not so!
Mount Sumeru is in the middle of the four continents, and the sun revolves around Mount Sumeru, illuminating the four continents:
When it is noon in Uttarakuru, it is sunrise in Purvavideha, and in Purvavideha it is the east;
when it is noon in Purvavideha, it is sunrise in Jambudvipa, and in Jambudvipa it is the east.
This is not really the beginning. Why is it so?
All directions are the east, all are the south, all are the west, all are the north.
You say that where the sun rises is the east, where the sun travels is the south, where the sun sets is the west, and where the sun does not travel is the north, but this is not so!
Moreover, there are places where the sun does not reach, which are not the directions because they lack the characteristics of the directions.
Question:
I speak of the characteristics of the directions in one country, but you use the four countries to argue, therefore the east is not without a beginning.
Answer:
If in one country the sun is in conjunction with the east, this is called having a boundary. Because it has a boundary, it is impermanent. Because it is impermanent, it is not universal.
Therefore, direction is merely a name without reality.

ã€Treatiseã€‘ Question:
Whose spiritual power causes the ground to become jeweled?
Answer:
This is the Buddha's immeasurable spiritual power and transformation.
Some people have spells and magical methods, as well as various ghosts, spirits, dragon kings, and gods who can transform a small amount of things;
Causing the trichiliocosm to all become precious treasures, other people and Brahma kings are all unable to do so.
The Buddha enters the fourteen transformation minds in the fourth dhyÄna, which can cause the flowers, incense, trees, and all lands in the trichiliocosm to be adorned;

Why is this?
This world is adorned in order to expound the perfection of wisdom.
It is also adorned for the sake of the visiting bodhisattvas and devas and humans from the ten directions.

It is like when a person invites distinguished guests - if it is for a single household, they will adorn a single household; if it is for a single country, they will adorn a single country; if it is for a wheel-turning sage king, they will adorn the four continents; if it is for the king of the Brahma Heaven, they will adorn the trichiliocosm.

Also, for the sake of the multitude of people who see this transformation and adornment, they will give rise to the great mind, give rise to a pure and joyful mind, give rise to great deeds from the great mind, obtain great rewards from great deeds, and when experiencing the great rewards, give rise to the great mind again. In this way, it will increase and grow, and they will attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
For this reason, this world is transformed and becomes all jewels.

gold, silver, lapis lazuli, and crystal.
